content:
The "Tax Relief Certainty Act of 2011" repeals the sunset provisions of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 and the Jobs and Growth Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2003. The Secretary of the Treasury is required to make technical and conforming changes to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This Act also provides permanent relief from the individual Alternative Minimum Tax. The "Tax Relief Certainty Act of 2011" provides permanent relief from the individual Alternative Minimum Tax. The "Tax Relief Certainty Act of 2011" provides permanent relief from the individual Alternative Minimum Tax by modifying the exemption amount for taxpayers other than corporations. The Tax Relief Certainty Act of 2011 amends the exemption amounts for different taxpayer categories under the individual Alternative Minimum Tax. For unmarried individuals and surviving spouses, the exemption is 25 percent of the dollar amount applicable under paragraph (1)(A). For married individuals filing separately, the exemption is 50 percent of the amount in paragraph (1)(A), and for estates or trusts, the exemption is $22,500. The term 'surviving spouse' is defined by section 2(a), and marital status is determined under section 7703. For taxpayers described in paragraph (1)(A), the Tax Relief Certainty Act of 2011 adjusts exemption amounts for different categories under the individual Alternative Minimum Tax. The exemption amounts for taxable years from 2011 to 2018 are as follows: $74,450 in 2011, $78,250 in 2012, $81,450 in 2013, $85,050 in 2014, $88,650 in 2015, $92,650 in 2016, $96,550 in 2017, and $100,950 in 2018. From 2018 to 2021, the exemption amounts increased from $100,950 to $112,250. Taxpayers described in paragraph (1)(B) for tax purposes. The exemption amounts for taxable years from 2011 to 2018 are as follows: $48,450 in 2011, $50,350 in 2012, $51,950 in 2013, $53,750 in 2014, $55,550 in 2015, $57,550 in 2016, $59,500 in 2017, and $61,700 in 2018. The exemption amounts increased steadily from $61,700 in 2018 to $68,200 in 2021. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to limit the aggregate amount of credits allowed for the taxable year based on the taxpayer's regular tax liability and the tax imposed by section 55(a). Conforming amendments are made to the Child tax credit sections. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to limit credits based on regular tax liability and section 55(a). Amendments are made to the Child tax credit sections, including changes to section 25(e)(1)(C) regarding the applicable tax limit. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including changes to the Savers' credit, residential energy efficient property credit, and certain plug-in electric vehicles credit. Carryforward of unused credits is allowed if the limitation imposed by section 26(a) is exceeded. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including changes to the Savers' credit, residential energy efficient property credit, and certain plug-in electric vehicles credit. Carryforward of unused credits is allowed if the limitation imposed by section 26(a) is exceeded. Section 30 of the Code is amended to adjust the personal credit for plug-in electric vehicles. Section 30D(c)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to treat the credit for plug-in electric vehicles as a credit allowable under subpart A. Additionally, amendments are made to sections 55(c)(3), 904, and 1400C(d) of the Code. Section 1400C(d) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow for the carryforward of unused credits to the succeeding taxable year. The Adoption credit under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act is repealed, and the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is to be applied as if the section had never been enacted. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow for the carryforward of unused credits to the succeeding taxable year if the credit exceeds the limitation imposed by section 26(a). The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow for the carryforward of unused credits to the succeeding taxable year. Section 23(c) is also amended, and the changes apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2010. TITLE III--PERMANENT ESTATE TAX RELIEF

SEC. 301. PERMANENT ESTATE TAX RELIEF.

Repeals Title III of the Tax Relief, Unemployment Insurance Reauthorization, and Job Creation Act of 2010, and its amendments, applying the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 as if those provisions had never been enacted. The repeal is effective for estates of decedents dying, gifts made, and generation skipping transfers after December 31, 2009.
